revision.text:
{{for|the similarly named yet unrelated forces outside of the context of the Turkish war|Serbian Volunteers (disambiguation)}} {{infobox military unit |unit_name= Serbian Free Corps |image=Serbian Free Corps soldier.jpg |caption=Illustration of a volunteer |dates= 1787 — 1792 |country= {{flagicon|Habsburg Monarchy}} [[Habsburg Monarchy]] |allegiance=Habsburg Monarchy |branch= |type= |role=Serbian liberation and unification with the Habsburg Monarchy |size=5–8,000 |command_structure= |garrison=In [[Banat Military Frontier]] |garrison_label= |nickname= ''frajkori'' |patron= |motto= |colors= |colors_label= |march= |mascot= |equipment= |equipment_label= |battles= [[Austro-Turkish War (1787–91)]]: *[[Siege of Belgrade (1787)]] *[[Siege of Belgrade (1788)]] |anniversaries= |decorations= |battle_honours= |battle_honours_label= |disbanded=1792 ([[Treaty of Sistova]]) <!-- Commanders --> |commander1= [[Mihailo Mihaljević]], major |commander1_label= Main commander |commander2= |commander2_label= |commander3= |commander3_label= |commander4= |commander4_label= |notable_commanders= [[Koča Anđelković]] [[Stanko Arambašić]] and [[Radič Petrović]] <!-- Insignia --> |identification_symbol= |identification_symbol_label= |identification_symbol_2= |identification_symbol_2_label= |identification_symbol_3= |identification_symbol_3_label= |identification_symbol_4= |identification_symbol_4_label= }} The '''Serbian Free Corps''' ({{lang-de|Serbische Freikorps}}), known simply as '''''frajkori''''' ({{lang-sr-cyr|фрајкори}}), was a volunteer [[militia]] composed of ethnic [[Serbs]], established by the [[Habsburg Monarchy]], to fight the [[Ottoman Empire]] during the [[Austro-Turkish War (1787–91)]]. The conflict with Turkish forces ultimately proved inconclusive. The rebellion in the [[Sanjak of Smederevo]] and militia's operations resulted in the [[Habsburg-occupied Serbia (1788–92)|period of Habsburg-occupied Serbia]], which took place from 1788 to 1792. Ultimately, the Serbian volunteer corps had the legacy of promoting the creation of future paramilitaries, such as during the [[First Serbian Uprising]].
==History==
A Serbian ''[[freikorps]]'' of 5,000 soldiers had been established in [[Banat]] ([[Banat Military Frontier]]), composed of refugees that had fled earlier conflicts in the Ottoman Empire.<ref name="Schroeder1996">{{cite book|author=Paul W. Schroeder|title=The Transformation of European Politics, 1763-1848|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=BS2z3iGPCigC&pg=PA59|year=1996|publisher=Oxford University Press|isbn=978-0-19-820654-5|pages=58–59}}</ref> The Corps would fight for liberation of Serbia and unification under Habsburg rule.<ref name="Schroeder1996"/> The main commander was the Austrian major [[Mihailo Mihaljević]].{{sfn|Ćorović|2001}} There were several freikorps along the Habsburg-Ottoman frontier.<ref name=GSUD20-69>{{cite book|title=Glasnik Srpskoga učenog društva|volume=20|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=RkwBAAAAMAAJ&pg=PA69|year=1866|pages=69–}}</ref> Mihaljević's Free Corps, the most notable, was active from [[Šumadija]] to [[Podrinje]], and across the [[Great Morava|Morava]] there was the Braničevo Free Corps; in Croatia the St. George Free Corps; in Bosnia they were called ''[[Seressaner]]''.<ref name=GSUD20-69/> Other Serb militias were the Kozara Militia and Prosar Militia, established in Bosnia in 1788, composed of 1,000 soldiers each.<ref name="Mihić1987">{{cite book|author=Ljubo Mihić|title=Kozara: priroda, čovjek, istorija|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=opsMAAAAIAAJ|year=1987|publisher=Dnevnik|quote=prosarska i kozarska milicija}}</ref>
Among volunteers were [[Aleksa Nenadović]] and [[Karađorđe Petrović]], [[Stanko Arambašić]] and the prominent [[Radič Petrović]] and most distinguished of all, [[Koča Anđelković]].{{sfn|Ćorović|2001}} The Orthodox clergy in Serbia supported the rebellion.<ref name="Mileusnić1994">{{cite book|author=Slobodan Mileusnić|title=Medieval monasteries of Serbia|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=ZzMtAQAAIAAJ|year=1994|publisher=Prometej|page=100}}</ref>
Koča's militia quickly took over Palanka and [[Batočina]], attacked [[Kragujevac]], and reached the Constantinople road, cutting off the Ottoman army from [[Sanjak of Niš]] and [[Sanjak of Vidin]].<ref name="DamnjanovićMerenik2004">{{cite book|author1=Nebojša Damnjanović|author2=Vladimir Merenik|title=The first Serbian uprising and the restoration of the Serbian state|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=eXFpAAAAMAAJ|year=2004|publisher=Historical Museum of Serbia, Gallery of the Serbian Academy of Science and Arts|page=46}}</ref>
The Austrians used the Corps in two failed attempts to seize Belgrade, in late 1787 and early 1788.<ref name="Schroeder1996"/>
==Organization== According to a document from 6 November 1789, the Free Corps included 1 squadron of [[hussars]], 18 companies of [[fusilier]]s, and 4 companies of [[musketeer]]s, with a total of 5,049 soldiers.<ref name=GSUD20-69/>
==Dress== Their uniforms were similar to that of the frontiersmen, with some changes.<ref name=MZ78-120>{{cite book|title=Mitološki zbornik|volume=7-8|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=PSQkAQAAIAAJ|year=2002|publisher=Centar za mitološki studije Srbije|page=120|quote=који је имао униформу налик граничарској, уз неке измене. Ти добровољци су имали: високе црне капе-чакове, кратку црну блузу с кратку црну блузу с црвеним гајтанима испод које је био прслук исте боје. Прслук је имао појас где су били задевани пишгаљи и ханџар. Чакшире су биле у облику пан- талона - које су се сужавале, налик коњичким брич-панталонама, које су падале преко високих црних цокула-ципела. Добровољци су носили пушку, хусарску сабљу, а на леђима ранац са каба- ницом и огртачем увијеним у ролну. Ова одећа је ипак при- лагођена Србима граничарима, да би је ови, са више воље носили и прихватили. Године 1793, Аустријанци формирају нови фрајкор "на гра- ници Турске" - за Србијанце и Босанце. Ови фрајкори били су, на згражавање Аустријанаца, веома шаролико одевени у широке панаталоне различитих боја, које су се ...}}</ref>
==Aftermath== In 1793, the Austrians established the new free corps on the border, for Serbians and Bosnians.<ref name=MZ78-120/>
==Legacy== On the eve of the [[First Serbian Uprising]], the [[Užice]] and Sokol nahije established volunteer detachments, called ''frajkori'', that had the task of sabotage against Ottoman military plans, and their concentration in this region of Serbia.<ref name="Зечевић">{{cite book|author=Слободан Зечевић|title=Гласник Етнографског музеја у Београду књ. 41: Bulletin of the Ethnographic Museum in Beograd|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=XTxuBgAAQBAJ&pg=PA125|publisher=Etnografski muzej u Beogradu|pages=125–|id=GGKEY:WCW551LA5H8}}</ref>
==Notable people== *[[Mihailo Mihaljević]], major *[[Koča Anđelković]], captain {{KIA}}1789 *[[Aleksa Nenadović]] *[[Karađorđe Petrović]] *[[Stanko Arambašić]] *[[Radič Petrović]] *[[Vuča Žikić]] *[[Petar Čardaklija]], captain
==See also== {{commonscat}} *[[Serbian Militia]] *[[Serbian Militia (1718–39)]]
==References== {{reflist}} ==Sources== *{{cite book|last=Ćorović|first=Vladimir|authorlink=Vladimir Ćorović|year=2001|origyear=1997|title=Историја српског народа|url=http://www.rastko.rs/rastko-bl/istorija/corovic/istorija/index.html|chapter=Kočina krajina|chapter-url=http://www.rastko.rs/rastko-bl/istorija/corovic/istorija/6_15.html|language=Serbian|publisher=Јанус|location=[[Belgrade]]|ref=harv}} *{{cite book|author=Dragoljub M. Pavlović|title=Srbija za vreme poslednjeg austrijsko-turskog rata: 1788-1791 g|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Aow6AQAAIAAJ|year=1910|publisher=Srpska kraljevska akademija}}
